headline.main: Smoke Out: A Lesson Before Lighting Up

docs.abstract: Thousands of students across Connecticut participate in interactive science program, Web site, billboard campaign and other projects that are being financed by state's portion of funds from settlement of lawsuits against tobacco industry; photos (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: ANTHONY COVINGTON looked appalled and emphatically shook his head when asked by a visitor whether he smoked cigarettes. Anthony, a fifth-grader at the Harry A. Conte West Hills Magnet School in New Haven, is one of thousands of students across the state who is learning what tobacco can do to the body through a program called Science, Tobacco and You. During a recent science lesson, Anthony, 10, was using an interactive CD-ROM program to study how smoking burdens the heart, lungs and circulatory system.
